nodes.bodyText: This means we wait for the build in actions.yml to complete successfully? Is that job uniquely identified, i.e. what happens if we ever add a third yml for whatever reason? Could this step here then be completed by that other job workflow?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+# This workflow will build a Java project with Gradle
+# For more information see: https://help.github.com/actions/language-and-framework-guides/building-and-testing-java-with-gradle
+
+name: Release
+
+on:
+  create:
+    tags:
+      - 'releaseTrigger'
+
+jobs:
+  deploy:
+    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+    name: releasing
+    steps:
+      - name: Wait for build to succeed
+        uses: jitterbit/await-check-suites@v1
+        with:
+          appSlugFilter: 'github-actions'
+          timeoutSeconds: '300'

nodes.bodyText:
This means we wait for the build in actions.yml to complete successfully?

yes

Is that job uniquely identified, i.e. what happens if we ever add a third yml for whatever reason?

No currently we wait for all test suites which are running on the same git SHA to be finished, not one particular, but all checks from github actions

Could this step here then be completed by that other job workflow?

Not completed but it will be a necessary step to wait for

+          timeoutSeconds: '300'

nodes.bodyText: That's good to know (can you add a short comment explaining that?). I wondered whether we should try to limit this to the actual checks that are currently configured, but I think waiting for all to be successful (they need to be successful, right?) is safer. This way, when we add a new job, the worst that can happen is the release not getting triggered.

nodes.bodyText: This means a broken release requires manual cleanup of the tag. Would that be a reason to perform this step much earlier, i.e. as the first one?

@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+# This workflow will build a Java project with Gradle
+# For more information see: https://help.github.com/actions/language-and-framework-guides/building-and-testing-java-with-gradle
+
+name: Release
+
+on:
+  create:
+    tags:
+      - 'releaseTrigger'
+
+jobs:

+        with:

+      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
+      - name: Setup java
+        uses: actions/setup-java@v1
+        with:
+          java-version: 8
+      - name: Perform Release
+        uses: eskatos/gradle-command-action@v1
+        env:
+          TRAVIS_BRANCH: master
+          TRAVIS_COMMIT_MESSAGE: <no commit message, not needed, we do not care about them, if we trigger or not>
+          TRAVIS_PULL_REQUEST: false
+          GH_WRITE_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GH_WRITE_TOKEN }}
+          BINTRAY_USER_NAME: ${{ secrets.BINTRAY_USER_NAME }}
+          BINTRAY_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.BINTRAY_API_KEY }}
+          NEXUS_TOKEN_USERNAME: ${{ secrets.NEXUS_TOKEN_USERNAME }}
+          NEXUS_TOKEN_PASSWORD: ${{ secrets.NEXUS_TOKEN_PASSWORD }}
+        with:
+          arguments: ciPerformRelease
+      - name: Delete Tag
+        run: git push --delete origin releaseTrigger

nodes.bodyText: that is a really good question -> we also should think ob some kind of notification in the error case. Or we can also provide a flag, which will continue the job, even if it failed. That is something hard to tell, which we should define. I do not have any special preferences regarding that :)

nodes.bodyText: I think it's bad enough that we abuse tags this way, we shouldn't go further and build an entire protocol based on them. 😉 The check marks next to each commit will show how the build went. Additionally, you can configure Bintray to send you an email for each release.

nodes.bodyText:
I think we can use this feature:
https://help.github.com/en/actions/reference/context-and-expression-syntax-for-github-actions#job-status-check-functions
Per default, steps only run "when none of the previous steps have failed or been canceled". Using if: ${{ always() }} seems to be a good fit for clean-up tasks like this.
(Sorry, haven't found time for a full review so far.)
